'''Thomas Bassett Macaulay''', also known as '''T. B. Macaulay''', (6 June 1860–1942) was born in [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]. He was a noted [[actuary]] of his era; a [[philanthropist]]; and was the founder of the [[Macaulay Institute]], in 1930. It has been estimated that most of the world's [[Holstein cattle]] descend from Macaulay's herd.

==Background==
Thomas Bassett Macaulay was the son of the [[Scotland|Scottish]] born [[Robertson Macaulay]] (1833–1915), who emigrated to Canada in 1854.<ref name="virtualmuseum1">{{Cite web|url=http://virtualmuseum.ca/pm.php?id=story_line&lg=English&fl=0&ex=00000161&sl=2435&pos=1 |title=Start of T. B. Macaulay (1860 - 1942) |accessdate=11 February 2010 |work=www.virtualmuseum.ca }}</ref> The family were descendants of the [[Macaulay family of Lewis]], and were patrilineal descendants of the 17th century [[Uig, Lewis|Uig]] folk-hero [[Stac Dhòmhnaill Chaim|Donald Cam Macaulay]].<ref name="L3-202205">{{Cite book|ref=L3 |last=Lawson |first=Bill |title=Lewis in History and Legend: The West Coast |date=2008 |publisher=[[Birlinn Limited|Birlinn]] |isbn=978-1-84158-368-6 |pages=202–205}}</ref> Robertson Macaulay married Barbara Marie Reid, and moved his family to [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada when he was offered a position there with [[Sun Life Assurance Company]].<ref name="virtualmuseum1"/> He joined as a [[secretary]] in 1874; by 1889 he had worked his way up to [[president]].<ref name="virtualmuseum1"/><ref name="macaulay1"/>

==Life==
Thomas Bassett Macaulay graduated [[high school]] and joined [[Sun Life]] at the age of 17. For the next forty years he worked for the company as [[actuary]] (aged 20), secretary, [[managing director]] (46), president (55).<ref name="virtualmuseum1"/><ref name="macaulay1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.macaulay.ac.uk/aboutus/MIhistoricalbook.pdf |format=[[pdf]] |title=Dr Thomas Bassett Macaulay |accessdate=11 February 2010 |work=www.macaulay.ac.uk }}</ref> He served as president for 20 years, before his retirement as [[chairman]].<ref name="virtualmuseum1"/>

Macaulay was a Fellow of the [[Institute of Actuaries]] of [[Great Britain]]. He was one of four [[Canadian]] charter members of the [[Society of Actuaries|Actuarial Society of America]].<ref name="macaulay1"/> In 1899, he became the first Canadian to be president of the society; as well as its youngest president, at age 39. When he died in 1942, Macaulay was also the longest surviving charter member.<ref name="soa1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.soa.org/library/proceedings/record-of-the-society-of-actuaries/1980-89/1986/january/RSA86V12N4A2.PDF |format=[[pdf]] |title=Dreams Of Our Founding Fathers |accessdate=12 February 2010 |work=[[Society of Actuaries]] }}</ref> Macaulay represented the actuaries of both Canada and the [[United States]] at the International Congresses, held in [[Paris]] and [[Berlin]], in the years 1900 and 1906. He was also a Fellow of the [[Royal Statistical Society]], President of the Canadian Life Assurance Officers' Association, and President of the Canadian West Indian League, and became an honorary president of the [[Navy League of Canada]]. In 1917, he was the Chairman of the National Committee on Food Resources, he also was the governor of the [[Montreal General Hospital]], as well as the Fraser Institute Public Library.<ref name="macaulay1"/>

Macaulay created a fund of £10,000 to assist the seafaring people of his father's home-town, [[Fraserburgh]], [[Aberdeenshire]], Scotland. He also gave £10,000 to research into animal breeding, at [[Edinburgh University]]. He also gave money to the public library on the Hebridean island of [[Lewis]], erected a wing in the island's hospital, and established the Macaulay Experimental Farm. In 1930, he funded the purchase of {{convert|50|acre|m2}}, to establish the [[Macaulay Institute for Soil Research]]. Macaulay received an [[honorary degree]] from the [[University of Aberdeen]],<ref name="macaulay1"/> and [[McGill University]],<ref name="virtualmuseum2"/> and the Lewis town of [[Stornoway]] made him the first Freeman of the burgh in 300 years.<ref name="macaulay1"/>

==Holstein herd==
[[File:Cow_female_black_white.jpg|thumb|Many of the world's [[Holstein cattle]] descend from Macaulay's herd. ]]

It has been stated that most of the world's pure-bred [[Holstein cattle]] descend from Macaulays herd, raised on his farm in [[Quebec]].<ref name="macaulay1"/><ref name="museevirtuel-virtualmuseum1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.museevirtuel-virtualmuseum.ca/Search.do?ex=on&R=VE_1387&lang=en |title=T.B. Macaulay and Mount Victoria Farm |accessdate=13 February 2010 |work=www.museevirtuel-virtualmuseum.ca }}</ref> Macaulay and farm manager, Joe Chandler, bought a bull named "Johanna Rag Apple Pabst" (also known as "Old Joe"), for $15,000. The bull sired 51 sons and 44 daughters; after Macaulay's death in 1942, the herd was dispersed and went on to produce most of the pure-breds in the world.<ref name="virtualmuseum2">{{Cite web|url=http://virtualmuseum.ca/pm.php?id=story_line&fl=0&lg=English&ex=00000161&sl=2435&pos=15 |title=Start of T. B. Macaulay (1860 - 1942) |accessdate=12 February 2010 |work=www.virtualmuseum.ca }}</ref><ref name="museevirtuel-virtualmuseum1"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.agrinewsinteractive.com/archives/article-5346.htm |title=Holstein pioneers make pilgrimage to area |author=Zandbergen, Nelson |date = October 2003|accessdate=12 February 2010 |work=www.agrinewsinteractive.com }}</ref> For his work as a breeder and farmer and his devotion to the advancement of agriculture in the province of [[Quebec]], Thomas Bassett Macaulay was posthumously inducted to the [[Agricultural Hall of Fame of Quebec]] in 1992 <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.templeagriculture.org/hommage/71-macaulay |title= Thomas Bassett Macaulay |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=http://www.templeagriculture.org/ |publisher= [[Agricultural Hall of Fame of Quebec]] |accessdate=15 December 2014|language=French}}</ref>

==Family==
In 1881, Macaulay married Henrietta M. L. Bragg, from [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]], [[USA]]. Bragg was the niece of [[US Army]] [[army general|General]] [[Braxton Bragg|Bragg]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://virtualmuseum.ca/pm_v2.php?id=story_line&lg=English&fl=0&ex=00000537&sl=4166&pos=1 |title=T.B. Macaulay and Mount Victoria Farm |accessdate=16 August 2011 |work=www.virtualmuseum.ca }}</ref> The couple had one son, followed by three daughters, and finally another son. One of their children was [[Frederick Macaulay]], best known for his work on [[bond duration]]s.<ref name = "Fred">http://www.sfu.ca/~poitras/mac1.pdf</ref> Macaulay had two later marriages. In 1912, he married  Margaret Allan of [[London]], [[England]]; in 1920, he married Margaret Palin of [[Gloucester]], England. He did not have any children in his later two marriages.<ref name="virtualmuseum1"/>
